intro: Calia arizonica, commonly known as the Arizona calico, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its striking, colorful bracts that resemble petals, which are often more showy than the small, inconspicuous true flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh desert conditions. Its leaves are usually narrow and succulent, helping to conserve water in its native habitat. Calia arizonica is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes other flowering plants with similar morphological traits.
